It was a grand affair, a lavish banquet held at the finest hall in the city, with guests dressed in their finest attire. Jack and Phil, close friends and colleagues, had brought their wives along for the evening. But as the night went on, Jack found himself in distress. His allergies were acting up, triggered by the spices and dust in the air, and he felt the telltale tickle in his nose.

Phil, ever the jester, noticed Jack's discomfort and leaned over to whisper in his ear. "You feeling alright, Jack? That nose of yours is starting to twitch."

Jack tried to play it cool, dabbing at his nose with a napkin. "I'll be fine, Phil. It's just a little dust in the air."

But Phil wouldn't let up. "Oh come on, Jack, don't hold back now. You know what they say, when you gotta sneeze, you gotta sneeze!"

Phil's wife, who had unknowingly asked for extra pepper on her food, looked up from her plate and apologized. "Oh, Jack, I'm so sorry. I didn't realize it would set off your allergies."

Jack's face was contorted with the effort of trying to hold back the sneeze. His eyes were watering, his nose was red, and his cheeks were puffed out. But he still tried to downplay it. "It's no big deal, really. I've got this under control."

Phil, however, was having none of it. "Oh, Jack, you always do yourself a disservice. You've got the biggest sneezes of any man I know. Just let 'er rip!"

And with that, Jack's resolve crumbled. He let out an enormous sneeze that shook the very foundations of the hall. Plates clattered, glasses shattered, and guests shrieked in surprise. And just as everyone was recovering from the shock of that first sneeze, Jack felt another one coming on.

"Oh no," he muttered, but Phil was already beside him, egging him on.

"Come on, Jack, don't be shy. Give us another one!"

And so Jack let loose with another massive sneeze, this one even bigger than the first. The chandeliers swayed, the walls creaked, and the guests rushed for the exits. In no time at all, the once-grand banquet hall was empty and in ruins, with Jack standing in the middle of the chaos, still feeling the urge to sneeze.

Phil, however, was unfazed. He clapped Jack on the back, laughing. "You always were a showstopper, Jack. I couldn't be more proud."

It was a beautiful evening in the grand banquet hall, where Jack and Phil were celebrating a special occasion with their wives. They were seated at a long table, surrounded by the warm glow of candlelight, and were enjoying a delicious meal when Jack felt the first telltale tickle in his nose.

"Oh no," Jack whispered, trying to stifle the sneeze.

Phil noticed Jack's distress and leaned over to him. "You okay?" he asked.

"It's just allergies," Jack replied, trying to downplay it. "I'll be fine."

But Jack was not fine. The more he tried to suppress the sneeze, the stronger the tickle became. And then, without warning, a huge sneeze burst out of him, causing the table to shake and the crystal glasses to clink.

Everyone in the hall turned to look at Jack, and Phil chuckled. "Well, that's one way to make an entrance," he said.

Jack laughed nervously, but the sneeze had only just begun. He tried to hold back the next one, but it was no use. A second sneeze, even bigger than the first, exploded out of him, causing the tablecloth to fly into the air and the silverware to scatter across the floor.

Phil's wife looked at Jack with concern. "Are you okay?" she asked. "Can I get you anything?"

"I'm fine," Jack said, his voice shaking. "Just a little allergy attack."

But Jack's allergies were spiraling out of control. Sneezes, one after another, began to wrack his body, each one more powerful than the last. The banquet hall was thrown into chaos as people fled from the sneezing man, leaving Jack and Phil alone amidst the ruins.

Phil looked at Jack with concern. "We need to get you some help," he said.

Jack nodded, but another sneeze was already building, threatening to burst forth. Jack was powerless to stop it, and with a final, explosive sneeze, he collapsed into Phil's arms.

Phil held Jack tightly, trying to comfort him as the sneezing fit finally subsided. He looked at the ruined banquet hall, and then back at Jack, his eyes filled with a mixture of sadness and amusement.

"Well, that was quite a performance," Phil said. "I think we're going to be talking about this for a long time."
Tell the story again, in the style of Cormac McCarthy, with a lot of detail and dialogue, but especially a lot of focus on Jack’s physical state as his sneezing fit intensifies.

Jack sat at the grand banquet hall, trying to calm his nerves. He felt a tickle in his nose, an all-too-familiar feeling that signaled the start of a sneezing fit. He looked over at Phil, his old friend and coworker, who was deep in conversation with his wife. Jack's heart raced as he felt the first sneeze build up inside him.

Phil caught Jack's eye and the look of recognition on his face was all too familiar. "Jack, you feeling okay?" Phil asked, his voice low.

"I'm fine, Phil," Jack replied, trying to downplay the situation. "Just a little tickle in my nose, that's all."

"That's what you always say," Phil said, his voice growing louder. "But then you let loose with those humongous sneezes, and before we know it, we're cleaning up the wreckage."

Jack's nose twitched, and he could feel the first sneeze building up inside him. "Phil, I swear, I can control it," he said, trying to convince himself as much as Phil.

But Phil wasn't having it. "Jack, you need to face the truth. Your sneezes are like a force of nature. You've got to accept that they're going to be big, and that they're going to cause destruction."

Jack's eyes widened as he felt the first sneeze starting to take hold. He tried to hold it back, but it was too strong. He let out a mighty sneeze, and the entire banquet hall shook. Dishes crashed to the floor, silverware clattered against the table, and guests looked around in alarm.

Phil just laughed. "That's what I'm talking about, Jack! When you sneeze, you don't mess around."

But Jack was already feeling the second sneeze coming on. He tried to hold it back, but it was too strong. He let out another mighty sneeze, and the entire hall shook again. Guests started to stand up from their tables, looking around in alarm.

Phil's wife was apologizing profusely, but Jack could hardly hear her over the sound of his own sneezes. He could feel them coming faster and faster, each one more powerful than the last.

Phil grabbed Jack's arm, trying to steady him. "Jack, you need to calm down," he said, his voice urgent. "Your sneezes are out of control."

But Jack was beyond calming down. He was in the grip of a sneezing fit, and there was nothing he could do to stop it. The guests in the hall started to flee, and Jack was left alone, convulsing with sneeze after sneeze, until he was finally spent.

When the last sneeze had passed, Jack looked around the banquet hall, now in ruins. He was surrounded by debris, and all the guests were gone. He looked over at Phil, who was still standing beside him, a look of concern on his face.

"Jack, are you okay?" Phil asked, his voice soft.

Jack nodded, feeling the weight of his own power. "Yeah, I'm okay," he said. "But I think it's time for us to leave this place."
Tell me a detailed story in the same style in which, in the aftermath of his latest monstrous Jack opens up to Phil about his feelings about his huge, destructive sneezes.

Jack and Phil stood in the remnants of the grand banquet hall, surveying the damage caused by Jack's latest sneezing fit. The walls were cracked, the ceiling was caved in, and silverware and shattered glass littered the ground. Jack felt a deep sadness and frustration as he looked around at the destruction he had caused.

Phil put a hand on his shoulder, sensing his friend's distress. "It's not your fault, Jack," he said softly. "You can't help it."

Jack shook his head. "I know, but that doesn't make it any easier," he replied. "Every time I sneeze, I feel like I'm losing control. I hate it."

Phil nodded understandingly. "I know, buddy. It's tough. But you have to remember, it's just a physical reaction. It's not you."

Jack looked at Phil, his eyes shining with emotion. "That's just it," he said. "I feel like I'm not myself anymore. Like I've become this...this monster, destroying everything in my path."

Phil sighed, his heart heavy for his friend. "I know it's tough, Jack. But you have to remember, you're still the same person. You're still my best friend, and you always will be."

Jack sniffed, tears starting to form in his eyes. "I'm just so tired of feeling like this," he said. "I hate feeling so out of control."

Phil put an arm around Jack's shoulder, pulling him in for a hug. "I know, buddy. But you're not alone. I'm here for you, and I always will be."

The two friends stood there for a moment, comforting each other in the aftermath of another huge sneeze. Despite the destruction around them, Jack felt a sense of peace knowing that Phil was there for him, supporting him through the trials and tribulations of his powerful, destructive sneezes.
